HER PROCESS: Environmental Cognition. This is the processes involved in acquisition, storage, and recall of info about the physical environment. Cognitive maps are key to understanding environmental cognition. For example, my cognitive map of Cornell is heavily influenced by my interests in athletics. Since I am an athlete, if I were to draw how my brain draws out Cornell, there would be a great emphasis on the sports fields and bartels. #envpsy #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 This picture snapped at AD White Library illustrates paths and nodes (the intersection of paths), two key characteristics of legibility. Lynch defines legibility as the ease with which one can make sense of his/her environment. In addition to the elevated pathways, the designer of this space made another strategic choice to increase legibility by creating clearly-defined paths even on the main floor through contrasting carpet colors and patterns. The result is a space that feels comprehensible.

This illustrated the path, one element of cognitive map. This is the channel for students to walk around the campus, students will be pretty familiar with the path which connect the places they frequently visit. #envpsy #envpsyw2

Pictured above is the Palisades Mall in West Nyack, New York. This location specifically relates to the HER process of environmental cognition because it serves as a local landmark for residents here, and even travelers that pass by to get to their destination. Environmental cognition is familiarity of one’s environment and the Palisades Mall helps with cognitive mapping of the area. People use the mall to locate their relative location in terms of how far their destination is from the mall, and also use it to estimate the amount of time left to reach their destination. #envpsy #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 Lennon’s Bar in Bangkok. This is an example of personal space. The ceilings are really high here so people in the bar feel more comfortable being next to each other. It also promotes more interaction.

The HER process of environmental cognition manifests well in cognitive maps. I often find myself using elements of the environment to find my way around campus. Specifically, I utilize paths and can effectively memorize the path I take to my in-person classes and college town, using landmarks as reference points as well. In these two pictures I have the main paths I take from North Campus to Main Campus. The foot bridge takes me to DEA1500 discussion and ANSC1101 lecture. The auto bridge takes me to CHEM2070 lab and college town. #envpsy #envpsyw2

HER Process: Environmental Cognition

Part of what makes the suspension bridge at Fall Creek a great path and landmark is its beautiful natural scenery. You’ll often see visitors and students taking pictures here to capture the wonderful colors. #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 this relates to the HER process of environmental cognition because I see the sign and with the information I receive, I process and interpret it to mean that the arrow is pointing closer towards the exit
The ocean and rock landscape represent good edges to Perkins cove; they clearly define the boundaries which Perkins cove is in, since it’s a peninsula. #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 An example of environmental cognition. The signs on a bike trail use symbols to guide cyclists toward different paths at intersections/nodes. Meaning is constructed from these symbols through a key.

Cornell University’s Clock Tower is an excellent landmark, or point of external reference. The clock tower functions well as a landmark because it is extremely tall (can be seen from far away which is helpful for orientation and wayfinding) and is extremely distinct (looks very different from other buildings/landmarks on campus; easily recognizable). This relates to the HER Process of Environmental Cognition. #envpsy #envpsyw2

The Johnson Museum of Art is a great example of a landmark, or an external point of reference. It is distinctive due to its height and color difference in relation to everything else on the slope, making it a very visible landmark when trying to identify where you are located. Use of the Johnson museum as a point of reference is an example of environmental cognition. #envpsy #envpsyw2
Honeybees: because I live in college town, I am allowed to hang photos. Here I have hung a flag that reminds me of New England and their sports which I greatly enjoy.
Warren Hall is a major landmark for me on campus, as it was one of the first buildings I had class in at Cornell. #envpsyw2
This is an example of a path, one of the five components of a city that we studied in class. It also gets noisy at night, relating to another HER process we covered. #envpsy #envpsyw2

This is Sage Chapel on Cornell’s campus. It is a landmark to me because I pass it every day and also regularly get my COVID tests here, but it may not appear on everyone’s mental map of campus because it is not super distinct like the nearby clock tower is. My perception of Sage as a landmark is an example of environmental cognition. #envpsy #envpsyw2

This is an example of good interior public space. In terms of seating, this environment does very well as there’s plenty of it and it‘s also flexible. The way the setting is arranged makes it almost impossible for there to be crowding so this is a very good place to study since noise levels are low and also minimizes risk of COVID. #envpsy #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 ELEMENTS OF COGNITIVE MAPS: An example of a landmark. The McGraw Tower is one of the most well-known locations on Cornell’s campus. It acts as an external point of reference and helps students figure out their location on campus.

Ithaca’s clock tower is the perfect example of a good landmark. The tower is tall, distinct, and visible from many different angles on campus. It also helps new students like me know my relative position on campus and find my way around central campus.
#envpsy #envpsyw2
One of the elements of Cognitive Maps is landmarks. Above is the clock tower which a point of reference for me on Cornell’s campus #envpsy #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 Example of environmental cognition. This map of a floor of Donlon Hall shows that new residents may have trouble wayfinding. Residents move in with a schema that hallways are straight, so they may be confused by the dorm being split into three curving corridors.
This hanging art exemplifies gestalt’s principle of similarity; people see the circles and squares, instead of viewing 2 strings of circles and 2 strings of circle, square, circle. #envpsyw2

HER Process of Environmental Cognition. One could easily get lost in an area like this due to such an open area, and lack of signs. The shape of the road and borders are irregular, making it hard for a newcomer to follow. #envpsy #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 Pictured above is my local church in Ichondong(South Korea). This landmark is an important point of reference for the cognitive maps of people who live in Ichondong. Oftentimes, people would look for this church to orientate themselves and find in which part of the county they are currently located at.
HER process of environmental cognition is present here because I know this fire escape in the engineering quad from my first year at Cornell because I thought they were cool #envpsy #envpsyw2
#envpsy #envpsyw2 This is an example of crowding.  There are 3 people living here in a room designed for 2 and thus the amount of space each person has is inadequate.

Pictured here is the Washington Monument. Due to its status as a landmark, this space is widely known. Understanding the process of environmental cognition, we can observe that this space can be utilized to determine one’s position and direction in a general area. Furthermore, the use of paths leading to and from the landmark extending from various directions allows for such a process to occur. #envpsy #envpsyw2

Here is a prime example of environment cognition. The clock tower in the landmark is the clock tower. Because I am using this landmark to understand my orientation within a space, I can confirm that I am near Sage Hall #envpsy #envpsyw2

Location: Herbert F. Johnson Museum of Art
Caption: #envpsy #envpsyw2 This is a picture of my friends and I at Johnson Museum at 1:30am. Although Johnson Museum is a landmark on the Cornell Campus, it is not often recognized or placed within students' cognitive maps (which was apparent during our discussion activity). This might be because it is so close to the boundaries of campus as well as the boundaries between west campus and the Arts Quad. It is also on a slope and not particularly tall so maybe people can't see it as much, making it a less obvious landmark. This relates to the HER process of environmental cognition.

This logo shows gestault principles and therefore why environmental perception is constructive. It is seen as a triangle with lines through it rather than individual horizontal rows of different lengths put together, showing principles of good figure.#envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 This is West Campus, a part of campus that I’m very familiar with by now. I have a strong cognitive map of all the buildings’ relative locations, which is an example of the HER process environmental cognition, the process involved in acquisition, storage, and recall of information about the physical environment around me. My cognitive map is my way of remembering the arrangement of the West Campus buildings. The main walkway shown in the picture is also an example of a path, an element of cognitive maps.

Here is a photo I took of the Thurston Avenue Bridge at the Fall Creek Gorge from the vantage point of Fall Creek's suspension bridge overlooking Horseshoe Falls. I thought that the Thurston Ave Bridge makes an iconic landmark. Because I had lived in a Cayuga Heights apartment for my first year at Cornell (as a transfer), this bridge was always a part of my daily walks to and from class. It also served as a useful "centering" point for me, since I could visually note a path to central campus with the Arts Quad and Ho Plaza, to the Ag Quad/Bio Quad (by taking a left on Forest Home Dr. and crossing Bailey Hall's plaza), and to West Campus all at once. My mapping of campus demonstrates the HER process Environmental Cognition.

#envpsy #envpsyw2

In class we analyzed environmental cognition and the ways in which our perceptions shape how we remember and view things with our senses. Doing this in discussion section was fun because I got to see how other students viewed Cornell’s campus. I noticed that our experiences shaped our maps and determined what locations we deemed important to include in the maps. #envpsy

This is related to the her process environmental cognition. I have shown a landmark which is useful for identifying which part of Ujamaa residential college you are at. Making cognitive "maps" is a part of environmental cognition that people use to identify places. Landmarks like this clocktower are an early part of making a cognitive map when exploring a new place.

This is my dorm's floor plan at Mews. This relates to the HER process of environmental cognition, specifically interior environmental congnition. I think this space is very "legible." The floor plan is very straightforward; as can be seen in the picture, it is simply one long hallway. Orientation and wayfinding is quite easy in a dorm like this, compared to complicated floor plans in Dickson or Donlon. In conclusion, the space is legible as relating to environmental cognition. #envpsyw2

This is a picture of Beebe Lake on campus. The clock tower is a large part of my environmental cognition when it comes to knowing campus environment. It is a landmark and it is legible because of its height. #envpsy #envpsyw2

In lecture, we have been discussing cognitive maps and how certain features of a city or campus design can make the environment more legible for its inhabitants. One very distinct node on Cornell’s campus is Libe Slope itself— because of its size, elevation, and iconic overlook view of the lake and mountains, it is an easily recognizable portion of our campus. I would classify it as a node because it is at the intersection between West Campus and central campus— it’s a relatively large node at that. 
#envpsy #envpsyw2

Examples of environmental perception. These decorative dots painted on my wall demonstrate Gestalt, the idea that the whole is greater than the sum of the parts. Rather than seeing these dots as organic shapes that are just interlocking or next to each other, my brain interprets them as circles overlapping each other (in both photos) and forming a venn diagram of sorts (in the second photo) #envpsy #envpsyw2

Examples of environmental perception. These decorative dots painted on my wall demonstrate Gestalt, the idea that the whole is greater than the sum of the parts. Rather than seeing these dots as organic shapes that are just interlocking or next to each other, my brain interprets them as circles overlapping each other (in both photos) and forming a venn diagram of sorts (in the second photo) #envpsy #envpsyw2

This photo represents the HER process of environmental perception. Perception is constructive and is dependent on the environment you were raised in, and in class we learned that people of certain cultures who live in dense forests and never see out into the horizon have different depth perception than those who grow up in an environment where they are able to see far into the horizon. In this picture you can see that the closer trees appear larger and the farthest trees appear very tiny. While many will perceive this as a picture of a normal forest, some may perceive this as a picture of miniature trees if they are not used to viewing object from far away. #envpsy #envpsyw2

This is a view of the Latino Living Center on North Campus, my residential dorm for freshman year. #envpsy #envpsyw2 An example of Environmental Cognition featuring a landmark. The clock tower is a common landmark to Cornell students and is used to define the point between Ho Plaza and the Arts quad when creating a cognitive map.

Relating to the concept of environmental cognition, the archway in the middle of this picture could be seen as a landmark. It’s not taller  or larger than the other architectures nearby but it has an open space in front of it which creates a “dent” on this street and allow it to be easily distinguished from far away. The poles in front of the archway also defines an edge — marking the boundary between traffic and pedestrians. #envpsyw2 #envpsy

This photo relates to the HER process of environmental cognition. Environmental cognition relates to how easy it is for users to understand how a spaces is designed, or how legible it is.

My dorm has poor legibility in its layout and low environmental cognition. Examples of this are the room numbering system is not intuitive, and hallways branch of at unpredictable points.

As a result, the dorm tries to compensate for poor schemata by adding lots of signs. However, this is not the best way to resolve the problem because it adds to much information in an ineffective way.

#envpsy #envpsyw2

This photo of a map of Ithaca mall shows the main paths and landmarks the comprise the mall as a whole. Regal cinemas, target, and Best Buy are some of the most notable landmarks. Paths are clearly shown in white. Additionally, where multiple paths cross each other could be considered a node, like the central food court. #envpsyw2 #envpsy

#envpsy #envpsyw2 Home range. A kid in my neighborhood playing with his toy gun outside his house while his grandfather calls out from inside "zyada door mat jaana" (don't go too far away). For most kids in my locality (including me), the home range while growing up is the enclosed apartment complex where they live, within which they can play wherever they want to, but not go outside on their own.

This week we learned about the HER Process: Environmental Cognition. Environmental Cognition is the process involved in acquisition, storage, and recall of information about the physical environment. In our section this week we each created our own cognitive maps of Cornell, this is how I view campus. This showed how our perception, and cognition is constructive as we all had different elements on our maps.

#envpsy #envpsyw2 An example of Noise. This is a video looking at one of the frosted glass walls in my studio classroom. More important is the level and type of sound coming from the massive ventilation system hanging from the ceiling. It gives everyone a headache and probably tampers with our ability to learn and focus on a task.

HER Process: Environmental Cognition
This is an example of an landmark that helps students determine where they are on campus. It helps me realize that I am almost at my dorm. #envpsy #envpsyw2

HER Process: Environmental Cognition. This is a picture of the path nestled in between Risley Hall and the tennis courts and butting up against Thurston Ave. I live off campus on north campus. To me, like probably a bunch of people on north campus, I would call this area a “node” in terms of cognitive maps and Kevin Lynch’s framework. Not only is this a spot where multiple paths converge, but it is also an entry point onto campus. It is very subtle, unlike the Cornell sign over by college town, but it communicates to those walking on the path that you are entering campus. In fact, recently walking through it in COVID times, I notice a lot of people put on their masks as they walk through this node, as if they also understand subtly that this is an entrance to campus where masks are required at all times. 

#envpsy #envpsyw2

This photo is an example of the gestalt law called good figure. The good figure law states people see individuals objects grouped together as whole figures. In this photo, rather than seeing individual Post-It notes, we see a heart. This relates to the HER process of environmental perception. This HER process states that sensory information is dynamically processed, organized, and perceived. This perception is influenced by how objects are grouped because environmental perception is a constructive process. #envpsy #envpsyw2

Schemata is a concept in the HER process of Enivronmental perception and cognition. It refers to structural organization imposed on stimuli from the environment; the perception is prototypic biases and based on expectation. For example, our stereotype of space and room will lead to an interesting illusion. This is the picture I took of my friends from the 3-D illusional museum. Similat to the trapezoid room example mentioned in Lecture (Oct.26.2020), the size of the chair is not like normal , and we were not standing on the same line. This unexpected arrangement does't fit our expection and lead to this funny situation .#envpsyw2

this is an example of cognitive maps in environmental cognition. these students are debating whether these 3 states are in correct relative geographic position, but it takes them a long time to come to an answer because of the 180-degree rotation. #envpsy #envpsyw2

This photo relates to the HER process of environmental cognition. I am a student in CAS so the arts quad is something that is really familiar to me however, something like the engineering quad is a place on campus that I am not familiar with. I know a lot of shortcuts and paths on the arts quad as well. I also consider the statue outside of GWS a node - it is a good meeting place and a spot of convergence. #envpsy #envpsyw2

#envpsy #envpsyw2 An example of environmental cognition. I live in the Inwood area of New York City. Someone unfamiliar with this area might not be able to navigate it as well as I can, even going down this one street. My cognitive map of Inwood is very detailed, whereas a person from Midtown might not have much knowledge about the area.

#envpsy #envpsyw2 Environmental Cognition. Environmental Cognition is the process in which one understands a place around them. This three-way intersection a short distance from North Campus and the windy roads connecting to it exemplify a lack of clear order to the streets and edges beyond campus. As such, it is hard to conceptualize the positioning of landmarks, such as Sunset Park, in relation to the North Campus district.
